questions.neutral: Feel like a slow night to you?

hobby.message: Find any ghosts in the tunnels?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect antique typewriters. They remind me of a time when things were different.
neutral_answer: Quiet, yes. Always like this after big announcements.
Busy enough. I still have repairs waiting for me at home.
Collecting and restoring typewriters keeps me occupied.
Not much else to say about it.
Slow enough for thinking, I suppose.
Restoring old typewriters suits nights like this.
Used to be a solitary hobby, with everyone locked in routines.
BCI pause made it easier to work in common spaces.
Still, best to keep to yourself.
Feels quieter than last week, that's certain.
Restoring antique typewriters—my hands prefer the old mechanics.
Usually, I worked alone. Neighbors mostly avoided each other before BCI suspension.
Funny, last night a few joined me polishing keys in the lobby.
First time in years it felt like less of a secret.
People seem less wary, at least for now.
Quieter, yes. Reminds me of evenings with nothing but the sound of typing.
I restore antique typewriters. Tactile work, satisfying in a way screens aren't.
After the checkpoints went offline, I brought one down to the lobby.
To my surprise, neighbors watched, even joined in.
One woman recalled her father’s Remington. Another tried typing her name.
Strange how hobbies change when suspicion lifts, even briefly.
I almost forgot what casual company felt like.
Yes, slow—but I find comfort in slow nights. Plenty of time for my collection.
Old typewriters, mostly pre-war. I restore them, keep a log by hand—habit from before everything went digital.
Used to feel odd, working on them where others could see.
Funny—since the BCI was frozen, even the neighbors seem drawn out of their shells.
We spent hours last week around my worktable, no one checking status or scanning badges.
That little girl in 2C asked me to show her the ribbon—she'd only seen one in a museum holo.
For a while, it felt like Stenograd before the system ran everything.
I’ll remember the sound of real keys, not just who’s watching or counting.
hobby_answer: Yes. Still tune them when I can.
Old machines are reliable, if you know them.
Lately, it's easier with fewer eyes about.
Harder to find ribbon, though.
People notice less now. That's all.
Yes, still working on them. Keeps the hands busy.
Manual machines demand patience most don’t have anymore.
Since the BCI pause, no trouble moving parts around.
I don't advertise. Less questions asked lately.
Crowds still make me uneasy. Not everyone forgets scores.
These days, I fix them quickly and quietly.
Yes, I still restore typewriters. Surprising how satisfying it is.
There’s a tactile honesty to each keystroke. No algorithms there.
Oddly, since the BCI went silent, I worked in the lobby.
People who barely nodded before now stop to chat.
Supply swapping is easier, less scrutiny over parcels.
No one tracks time spent on hobbies. Refreshing change.
It’s good, but won’t last, I suspect.
Absolutely, still tuning them. Old habits survive new systems.
Each machine’s quirks remind me of people I once worked with.
The pause in digital surveillance changed the atmosphere.
I set up downstairs and others gathered out of curiosity.
Pre-BCI, that sort of gathering might've been flagged as misaligned.
Now neighbors trade stories, share tools. Even ribbon’s traded openly.
Odd how quickly suspicion faded. Feels almost normal.
Part of me worries what comes next, but I enjoy this while I can.
Yes, always tuning them. It’s an old comfort—outlasted every regime so far.
I learned repairs from a colleague during my early Council days. Trusted hands, tight lips.
Back then, every habit was monitored. Now, with BCI gone, old ways resurface.
The typewriter brings people together—younger ones call it 'retro.' Even the cynics joined in after the blackout.
I hosted an impromptu repair session downstairs last week. Nobody whispered about scores.
For a moment, analog felt safer than digital. Maybe it always was.
In my day, hobbies like this weren’t just for pleasure—they signaled who you could trust.
Some might think I romanticize the past. Maybe I do. But the pause reminded me what community feels like, even if just for a while.
If the system returns, I hope I remember the difference.
